S0926-860X(16)30628-7 10.1016/j.apcata.2016.12.024 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Schematic drawing of experimental apparatus. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Temperature dependence of CO conversion rate for Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al catalysts. Experimental conditions: total pressure of 2.5MPa, H2O/CO ratio of 1.2mol/mol, H2S concentration of 500ppm, and GHSV of 20,000h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Time course of product amount in each elementary reaction of mechanism A. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Elementary-reaction progression rates in mechanism A for Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Schematic diagram of elementary reaction A2 to explain the effect of promoter α. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Dependence of CO conversion rate on H2S concentration for Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst. Experimental conditions: total pressure of 2.5MPa, H2O/CO ratio of 1.2mol/mol, and GHSV of 20,000h−1. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Elementary-reaction progression rates in mechanisms A and B for Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst. Fig. 7 Table 1 Composition of dry – feed gas. Research & Development Group, 7-1-1 Omika, Hitachi-shi, Ibaraki 319-1292, Japan. Hitachi, Ltd. Research & Development Group 7-1-1 Omika Hitachi-shi Ibaraki 319-1292 Japan Graphical abstract Assumed reaction mechanism of Mo-based shift catalyst. The reaction mechanism of molybdenum-based shift catalysts, which are sulfur-tolerant water-gas shift catalysts (sour-shift catalysts), were examined by elementary-reaction analysis. The elementary-reaction progression rate for a nickel/molybdenum/titanium (Ni/Mo/Ti) compound catalyst (as a low-temperature reactive catalyst) and cobalt/molybdenum/aluminum (Co/Mo/Al) compound catalyst (as a conventional catalyst) were investigated. The results of this investigation show that the elementary-reaction progression rate of the Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst is higher than that of the Co/Mo/Al catalyst at 200°C (which is representative of the low-temperature region). This tendency accorded with that of shift activity. This result suggests that the shift activity depends on improved dispersibility of active sites by the support effect of TiO2 and the strong electron-withdrawing effect of the nickel promoter. Moreover, separately from the reaction mechanism of the sour-shift catalyst proposed up to now, a new mechanism, by which H2S in reaction gas contributes to the progress of the shift reaction in the elementary reaction process, is proposed, and as a result of elementary-reaction analysis, we confirmed this new mechanism must be progressed. Keywords Water-gas shift reaction Sulfur-tolerant catalyst Elementary reaction Progression rate Ni/Mo/Ti 1 Introduction The water-gas shift (WGS) reaction is an industrial organic reaction that generally accompanies coal gasification and steam reforming, in which steam and hydrocarbons react at high temperature to generate hydrogen (from steam) and carbon monoxide (CO) in so-called “synthesis gas” (syngas) [1–5] according to the following equation: (1) C O + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 As catalysts to promote the WGS reaction, iron-chromium (Fe-Cr)-based catalysts can be used at temperatures of 300°C or higher, while copper-zinc (Cu-Zn)-based catalysts can be used below 300°C [6–8]. In the syngas process flow, the reactants must be desulfurized before they reach the catalyst reactor because the above-mentioned catalysts are contaminated by sulfur. Alternatively, sulfur-tolerant shift catalysts (sour-shift catalysts), such as iron-cerium (Fe-Ce)-based [9–12] as well as cobalt-molybdenum (Co-Mo)-based and nickel-molybdenum (Ni-Mo)-based catalysts [13–24], have been developed. In particular, Mo-based catalysts can be used over a wide temperature range, although they are active only when the reaction gas contains hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Previously, we developed a Ni-Mo-based catalyst with higher shift activity under conditions of low temperature and low-flow-rate steam supply than a proven Co-Mo-based commercial catalyst [25]. However, we did not clarify the reaction mechanism by which the developed Ni-Mo-based catalyst acts. Moreover, considering the elementary reactions of a reaction system, we did not clarify the elementary-reaction process that contributes to the higher shift activity of Ni-Mo-based catalysts at low temperature. The elementary shift reaction that is promoted by a sour-shift catalyst has been extensively researched. However, the mechanism proposed by many researches does not consider H2S, which is said to be an essential component in maintaining the activity of the sour-shift catalyst [22–24]. In various researches, H2S coexistence (at concentrations of several-hundred ppm) in reaction gas has been shown to be a requirement for actively maintaining a sour-shift catalyst [26,27]. Therefore, we supposed that another reaction mechanism in which H2S participates must be present in an elementary reaction process. In this study, we intended to clarify the two following points by elementary-reaction analysis of a sour-shift catalyst using a laboratory-scale apparatus. First, we examined the reason that the low-temperature activity of the developed Ni-Mo-based catalyst is higher than that of a conventional Co-Mo-based catalyst. Second, we examined the possibility that a new mechanism, in which H2S contributes to the progression of the shift reaction in elementary reactions, is taking place. In addition, before clarifying those two points, we examined the dependences of CO-conversion activity on temperature and H2S concentration. The objective of evaluating the temperature dependence was to clarify the difference between shift activities of Ni-Mo-based and Co-Mo-based catalysts under the same experimental conditions. Moreover, the objective of evaluating the H2S-concentration dependence was to confirm whether the shift activity of the developed sour-shift catalyst depends on H2S concentration as reported in many studies on Ni-Mo-based catalysts. 2 Method 2.1 Assumed reaction mechanism The shift-reaction mechanism proposed to date consists of three elementary reactions described by Eqs. (2)–(4) [22–24]. Hereafter, the overall mechanism is called “mechanism A” and each elementary reaction is respectively identified as “A1”–“A3.” As for mechanism A, MoS2 formed after sulfiding (which is a catalyst pretreatment) is a starting reagent. In A1, H2S is generated by a reaction with MoS2 and H2O, and MoS2 becomes MoSO. In A2, CO2 is generated by the reaction of the oxygen atoms in MoSO and CO in gas phase, and MoSO becomes MoS. In A3, H2 is generated by the reaction of MoS and H2O at the same time as MoSO is formed. The shift reaction progresses afterwards by repeating A2 and A3. In the above-described reaction system, although H2S coexistence is supposed to be required when a sour-shift catalyst is used, H2S does not participate in the elementary reactions. As mentioned above, H2S coexistence in the reaction gas (at a concentration of several-hundred ppm) is required to maintain the sour-shift catalyst. Therefore, we propose a new mechanism in which H2S contributes to the progress of the shift reaction in the elementary-reactions. This elementary reaction mechanism, hereafter designated as “B,” is described by Eqs. (2), (3), and (5). Mechanism B assumes elementary reaction B3 instead of A3; in other words, MoS reacts with H2S, not H2O. As for mechanism B, as the shift reaction progresses by repeating elementary reactions A1, A2, and B3, H2S participates in the elementary-reaction process. In the following, we examine the progression of the elementary reactions involved in mechanism A (which has been previously proposed) and mechanism B (which is newly assumed in this study). (2) ( A 1 ) M o S 2 + H 2 O → M o S O + H 2 S (3) ( A 2 ) M o S O + C O → M o S + C O 2 (4) ( A 3 ) M o S + H 2 O → M o S O + H 2 (5) ( B 3 ) M o S + H 2 S → M o S 2 + H 2 2.2 Catalyst The reaction mechanisms of a Ni/Mo/TiO2 catalyst (Ni/Mo/Ti, hereafter), which is active at low temperature, and for a Co/Mo/Al2O3-MgO catalyst (Co/Mo/Al hereafter), which has widely reported reaction characteristics [28–30], were examined first. Both catalysts were prepared by kneading and extrusion molding. Their compositions (wt%) are as follows: in Ni/Mo/Ti, NiO 5.0±1.0, MoO3 20.0±1.0, and TiO2 75.0±1.0; and in Co/Mo/Al, CoO 5.0±1.0, MoO3 15.0±1.0, Al2O3 60.0±1.0, and MgO 20.0±1.0. The particle sizes of both catalysts were 2.0mm in diameter and 3–10mm in length. 2.3 Catalyst pretreatment Sulfiding is a necessary pretreatment for a sour-shift catalyst [31,32]. Although the molybdenum contained in the catalyst after preparation is present as an oxide (MoO3), MoO3 must be converted into MoS2 before it is used to the shift reaction. The reaction that converts MoO3 to MoS2 is expressed as Eq. (6). The catalyst was pretreated by the following procedure. After the catalyst-bed temperature was increased to 200°C under N2 flow, H2 and H2S were added to produce H2 at 7 vol% and H2S at 3 vol%. After H2S at 1vol% or higher was detected at the catalyst-bed exit, the gas temperature was increased to 300°C at a rate of 1°C/min. The pretreatment ended after the catalyst bed had been kept at 300°C for 45min. (6) M o O 3 + 2 H 2 S + H 2 → M o S 2 + 3 H 2 O 2.4 Experimental equipment A schematic drawing of the experimental apparatus used for elementary-reaction analysis is shown in Fig. 1 . This apparatus is composed of a gas-supply system (labelled 1), a steam-supply system (2–4), a stainless-steel (SUS) tube reactor (5), an electric furnace (7), a pressure regulator (8), and moisture-removal devices (9 and 10). The reaction gas was a mixture of CO, CO2, H2, N2, and CH4 supplied from one cylinder and H2S and N2 supplied together from another cylinder. These gases simulated coal-gasification gas. The reaction gas flow was adjusted to 830mL/min by the flow meter (1) and supplied into the top of the tube reactor (with outside diameter of 21.3mm, inside diameter of 15.8mm, and length of 500.0mm). Steam was generated by supplying water to the vaporizer (4) from the water tank (2) with the plunger pump (3). The tube reactor was filled with catalyst (6). The pressure was adjusted by a pressure regulator installed under the tube reactor. After the shift reaction, a large amount of water vapor that had not been used in the reaction remained in the gas, and the moisture-removal devices removed it so it would not contaminate the analysis-gas sample. The concentrations of CO, CO2, H2, N2, and CH4 were determined by gas chromatograph analyzer, i.e., a Hitachi G-5000 TCD (thermal-conductivity detector). The concentrations of H2S and COS were determined by gas-chromatograph analyzer, i.e., a Shimadzu GC-2014 FPD (flame ionization detector). CO conversion rate was calculated from the catalyst inlet and outlet concentrations as follows: (7) C O ⁡ c o n v e r s i o n r a t e ⁡ ( % ) = C O i n − C O o u t C O i n × 100 C O i n : CO volume flow at catalyst inlet (ml/min) C O o u t : CO volume flow at catalyst outlet (ml/min). 2.5 Experimental conditions Dry-feed-gas composition and experimental conditions are listed in Tables 1 and 2 , respectively. As evaluations of shift-reaction activity, two different experiments were used to examine dependences of CO-conversion activity on temperature and H2S concentration. The same conditions were used for both experiments: dry-GHSV (reactant gas flow rate/catalyst volume) of 20,000h−1, H2O/CO ratio of 1.2mol/mol, and total pressure of 2.4MPa. To confirm the progression of each mechanism, following experiments were also carried out: gas composition at the catalyst outlet was examined when the reaction gas of each elementary reaction and nitrogen were supplied to the catalysts. That is, in the case of mechanism A, first, a mixed gas of steam (H2O) and nitrogen was supplied to the catalyst after pretreatment (A1). Next, a mixed gas of CO and nitrogen was supplied (A2). Lastly, a mixed gas of steam and nitrogen was supplied (A3). This procedure was also used for mechanism B. In the case of mechanism A, Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al were selected as experimental catalysts, and the experimental temperature was 200 and 400°C for Ni/Mo/Ti and 200°C for Co/Mo/Al. In the case of mechanism B, only Ni/Mo/Ti was selected and examined at 200 and 400°C. These two types of experiments were carried out in the same conditions: dry-GHSV of 10,000h−1 and total pressure of 2.4MPa. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Comparison of reaction-progression rate of Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al Temperature dependence of CO conversion rate for Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al is plotted in Fig. 2 . CO conversion rate for Ni/Mo/Ti is 47% at catalyst-inlet temperature of 200°C, increases gently up to 300°C, and decreases from 300°C to 400°C. The progress of the shift reaction is limited at high temperature by the chemical equilibrium because the shift reaction is exothermic. It seems that the shift reaction is affected by the reaction equilibrium because CO conversion rate decreases at high temperature. On the other hand, CO conversion rate of Co/Mo/Al is only 5% at catalyst inlet temperature of 200°C, and it increases with increasing catalyst inlet temperature afterwards. We supposed that the reaction start temperature for the Co/Mo/Al catalyst was between 250°C to 300°C because reactivity improved, particularly after catalytic inlet temperature of 250°C. Comparison of the activities of both catalysts confirmed that the difference in their activities at low temperature is significant. The reason that the low-temperature activity of the catalysts differs (as shown in Fig. 2) at reaction temperature of 200°C for mechanism A was investigated as follows. Change in gas-product amount for each elementary reaction with time is shown in Fig. 3 . The gases produced in elementary reactions A1, A2, and A3 were assumed as H2S, CO2, and H2 as shown in Eqs. (2)–(4). The gas production decreased for both catalysts and for each elementary reaction over time and hardly any gas was produced after 60min. We supposed that the molybdenum formed on the right side of each elementary reaction changed after 60min. Therefore, the amount of gas produced in each elementary reaction in 60min was calculated, and the ratio of that gas-production amount per hour and molybdenum content in a catalyst (production amount/Mo amount (h−1)) was defined as the progression rate of each elementary reaction. The elementary-reaction progression rate for each catalyst is compared in Fig. 4 . The figure confirms that the progression rate for the Ni/Mo/Ti is higher than that for the Co/Mo/Al in the case of each elementary reaction. This tendency accords with the order of the CO conversion rate shown in Fig. 2. In addition, when comparing the progression rate of each elementary reaction for both catalysts, that for the Ni/Mo/Ti is higher than that for the Co/Mo/Al catalyst. The progression ratios (Co/Mo/Al catalyst based) of elementary reactions A1, A2, and A3 are 1.4, 2.5, and 1.9, respectively. In particular, the difference of progression ratio for A2 is significantly larger. The effect of the support in each catalyst was considered as the reason that Ni/Mo/Ti had the larger progression rate than the Co/Mo/Al in each elementary reaction. As for the reason that catalyst activity depends on the support, it has been reported that the hydroxyl group influences catalyst activity [17,33,34]. In short, although molybdenum is dispersed on a support through a surface hydroxyl group, for example, by forming a Mo-O-Ti combination, the dispersibility of molybdenum is dependent on the quantity of the surface hydroxyl group (especially a Lewis-acid site). It is suggested that the amounts of surface hydroxyl group in the two supports examined in this study differ, causing the difference in catalytic activity. Although we did not intend to examine the quantity of surface hydroxyl groups in the support, it was reported that the amount of surface hydroxyl groups is more for TiO2 than Al2O3 and that CO conversion activity is increased by applying TiO2 to the support [17]. We reason from those reported facts that the active surface area is increased by widely dispersing molybdenum on the support; as a result, the progression rate of each elementary reaction was improved. Moreover, we consider the reason for the difference in progression rates for the Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al is mostly due to elementary reaction A2. In A2, CO2 is produced by CO colliding with MoSO and an oxygen atom being transferred to molybdenum. The elimination of the oxygen atom on the molybdenum would make the progression rates different for the Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al catalysts. This supposition is explained schematically in Fig. 5 . The oxygen atom in MoSO forms a cross-linked structure with promoter α (nickel or cobalt) and molybdenum. The electronegativity of nickel is higher than that of cobalt; thus, nickel is able to attract an electron more easily than cobalt can. Therefore, when nickel forms the cross-linked structure through the oxygen atom, it has a bigger potential to attract an electron in the oxygen atom than cobalt, and the Mo-O combination dissociates more easily with nickel. As a result, the progression rate of elementary reaction A2 differs greatly for each catalyst (as shown in Fig. 4). 3.2 Progression of reaction mechanism B Dependence of CO conversion rate on H2S concentration for the Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst is shown in Fig. 6 . CO conversion rates at 200°C are 17, 33, and 47% at H2S concentrations of 100, 200, and 500ppm, respectively. This result confirms that H2S concentration greatly influences the shift activity of the Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst. Therefore, assuming that H2S in the reaction gas contributes to the progress of the shift reaction in the elementary-reaction process, we examined the progression rate of mechanism B. Progression rates of each elementary reaction for mechanisms A and B for the Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst are compared in Fig. 7 . The figure confirms that hydrogen is generated in elementary reaction B3. Therefore, the progression of mechanism B was confirmed. Comparing the progression rates of elementary reactions of mechanisms A and B reveals that the progression rate at 400°C is bigger than that at 200°C in the case of both mechanisms. Elementary reactions A3 and B3 involve an oxygen atom in H2O or a sulfur atom in H2S enters an anion vacancy formed on molybdenum in elementary reaction A2. Elementary reaction B3 is similar to the sulfiding process expressed by Eq. (6). That is, oxygen atoms in MoO3 are pulled away by hydrogen (reduction) and an anion vacancy is formed, and MoS2 is finally formed because sulfur atoms in H2S enter the anion vacancy. The sulfiding reaction shown in Eq. (6) is temperature dependent, and it has been reported to progress easily at high temperature [35]. Therefore, H2O and H2S are activated at high temperature for elementary reactions A3 and B3, and the reaction progression rate is improved because the frequency of contact between the anion vacancy and H2O or H2S increases. Moreover, comparing elementary reactions A3 and B3 reveals that the progression rates of both at 200°C are almost the same, but that of A3 is bigger than that of B3 at 400°C. The difference between bonding energies of molybdenum and oxygen or sulfur is considered to be the reason for this behavior. As an index to compare the bonding energies of Mo-S and Mo-O, the standard enthalpies of formation (⊲fH) of MoS2 and MoO3 (which are stable compounds including each atom) are compared as follows. The standard enthalpies of formation of MoO3 and MoS2 at 700K are −739.3 and −288.9kJ/mol, respectively. The formation enthalpies per bond of Mo-O and Mo-S were calculated simply as ⊲fH as −246.4 and −144.5kJ/mol, respectively. In other words, the bonding energy of Mo-O is higher than that of Mo-S. This result suggests that the progression rates of each elementary reaction start to differ at high temperature, particularly because of the difference between bonding energy with molybdenum and bonding energy with molybdenum. 4 Conclusion The reaction mechanism for sour-shift catalysts was investigated by analyzing the elementary reactions involved in the mechanism. The results of this investigation can be summarized as three key points. First, for reaction mechanism A (previously proposed), elementary-reaction progression rates for a Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst (as a low-temperature reactive catalyst) and a Co/Mo/Al catalyst (as a conventional catalyst) were determined. The elementary-reaction progression rate of the Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst was higher than that of the Co/Mo/Al catalyst at 200°C. As one reason for this difference, we supposed that the TiO2 catalyst support has more surface hydroxyl groups that can combine with molybdenum than the Al2O3 support, so it enhances molybdenum dispersibility. Second, comparing the Ni/Mo/Ti and Co/Mo/Al catalysts reveal a significant difference in progression rates in the second step of the elementary reaction in which CO is converted to CO2. It is considered that nickel can withdraw an electron from the oxygen atom and the Mo-O combination (bond) is dissociated more easily than cobalt because the electronegativity of nickel is larger than that of cobalt. Third, mechanism B (in which H2S gas contributes to the progress of the shift reaction in the elementary reaction process) was newly proposed, and its progression rate was examined. We confirmed the progression ratio of mechanism B. References [1] W. Wan Z. Dai C. Li G. Yu F. Wang Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 15 2014 7811 7818 [2] T.L. LeVally A.R. Richard M. Fan Int. J. coredata.dc:description: The reaction mechanism of molybdenum-based shift catalysts, which are sulfur-tolerant water-gas shift catalysts (sour-shift catalysts), were examined by elementary-reaction analysis. The elementary-reaction progression rate for a nickel/molybdenum/titanium (Ni/Mo/Ti) compound catalyst (as a low-temperature reactive catalyst) and cobalt/molybdenum/aluminum (Co/Mo/Al) compound catalyst (as a conventional catalyst) were investigated. The results of this investigation show that the elementary-reaction progression rate of the Ni/Mo/Ti catalyst is higher than that of the Co/Mo/Al catalyst at 200°C (which is representative of the low-temperature region). This tendency accorded with that of shift activity. This result suggests that the shift activity depends on improved dispersibility of active sites by the support effect of TiO2 and the strong electron-withdrawing effect of the nickel promoter. Moreover, separately from the reaction mechanism of the sour-shift catalyst proposed up to now, a new mechanism, by which H2S in reaction gas contributes to the progress of the shift reaction in the elementary reaction process, is proposed, and as a result of elementary-reaction analysis, we confirmed this new mechanism must be progressed.
coredata.dc:title: Reaction mechanism analysis for molybdenum-based water-gas shift catalysts
